user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 msecs)
{
    struct timespec                     ts;
    int                                 result;
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    /*
     ** Compute an absolute time for the delay
     */
    OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime(msecs, &ts);

    if (sem_timedwait(&impl->id, &ts) == 0)
    {
        result = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else if (errno == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        result = OS_SEM_TIMEOUT;
    }
    else
    {
        /* unspecified failure */
        result = OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return result;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl:
OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_MAX_COUNT_SEMAPHORES]
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No occurrences of the string.h functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) are present in the provided code. The function body only uses: - OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime(&ts) — computes an absolute timespec (not a string operation). - sem_timedwait(&impl->id, &ts) — a POSIX semaphore wait (not from <string.h>). - errno and ETIMEDOUT handling — error/status checks (not string operations). - OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(...) and the array OS_impl_count_sem_table — table/macro access; the macro expansion is not shown but the use here is not a string.h call. There are no calls to standard string-handling functions, nor any obvious buffer/character-array manipulations in the shown code. Therefore there are no fragments in this function that need investigation specifically for Rule 21.17. (If callers or any of the referenced helper functions/macros — e.g., OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime or the expansion of OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — internally call string.h functions, those implementations would need to be inspected separately, but they are not part of the provided code.)
